 HAITI FOREST AND PARK PROTECTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX 1. BACKGROUND A. Country Overview 1.1 Social and Economic Setting. Haiti is a small, predominately rural, country. Its 7 million people occupy 28,000 square kilometers on the western end of the island of Hispaniola. With an estimated GNP per capita of below US$250 in 1994, Haiti is the poorest and one of the most densely populated nations in the Western Hemisphere. Social indicators are alarming. In 1994, an estimated 50 percent of the population had a caloric intake of below 75 percent of requirements, and over 25 percent of children suffered from malnutrition. The infant mortality rate is estimated to exceed 100 per 1,000 live births. Some 50 percent of adult Haitians are illiterate. Net of emigration of 0.5 percent, the population grew at a rate of 1.8 percent per year in the 1980s. Unemployment and under employment are estimated at 70 percent. 1.2 During 1980-91, Haiti's population suffered a continuing decline in its standard of living, with real GNP per capita falling by about 2 percent per year. Over decades, population pressure and poor public policies forced cultivation of increasingly marginal lands, and in turn accelerated deforestation and soil erosion. As a result, agricultural production, the main source of income of the 70 percent of the population who live in rural areas, has fallen steadily on a per capita basis since the 1970s. In the second half of the 1970s, an expansion in the export industry together with increasing public investment partially compensated for the decline in agriculture and allowed the country to grow at a rate of about 3 percent per capita. However, political instability during most of the 1980s put a stop to industrial expansion, investment, external assistance and economic growth. 1.3 Political stalemate during the 1991-1994 period coupled with the international embargo on Haiti aggravated economic decline. In 1990, President Aristide was democratically elected and took office in February 1991. His Government undertook measures to improve fiscal revenues, liberalize trade and improve infrastructure services, and initiated discussions on an IMF stand-by agreement. However, in September 1991, a military-led coup d'etat forced President Aristide from office and into exile. During the following three years, increased economic mismanagement and international rejection led to an international embargo, resulting in a dramatic decline in living standards. On October 16, 1994, President Aristide was able to return to Haiti, and on November 7, 1994, a new constitutional Government was appointed. During this period, economic performance deteriorated at an accelerated pace. Preliminary data indicate that real GDP fell by over 17 percent during 1992-93, and by a further 10 percent in 1994. All sectors
 - 2 - were affected, and the situation was further aggravated by the tropical storm Gordon which hit Haiti on November 12, 1994. Agricultural production and exports decreased considerably. Export oriented industries were devastated by the embargo. Value-added in the services sector decreased in line with GDP, and construction activities came to a virtual standstill. After peaceful elections in December 1995, Rene Preval, Prime Minister under Aristide's first Government in 1991, was elected and took office on February 7, 1996. 1.4 Forestry and Environmental Protection. Despite its small relative size, Haiti has an unusually broad diversity of ecosystems and endemic species. Ecosystems include alkaline, inland lakes, coastal mangrove forests, dry-scrub forests, savannas, and moist forests on peaks reaching almost 3,000 meters. About 30 percent of Haiti's plant and animal species are endemic to the island of Hispaniola: a greater percentage than is found in the larger and less environmentally degraded Dominican Republic. This biological richness is due to the wide range of rainfall and topography, and the fact that Haiti is a combination of two geologically distinct islands, one supporting a biology with origins in the North-American continent, and the other, the South American continent. The recently published, Global Environmental Facility (GEF) sponsored study, A Conservation Assessment of the Terrestrial Ecoregions of Latin America and the Caribbean, found that both the moist forest and pine forest ecosystems of Hispaniola were regionally outstanding. 1.5 Haiti's endowment of forest resources has been treated as a free good and exploited to capitalize economic development since colonial times. Europeans cleared mountain forests to establish coffee plantations and used clean-tilling agricultural practices that promoted soil erosion. European colonists and, then later, early Haitian governments harvested and exported timber (chiefly mahogany, ironwood, and logwood) to earn hard currency. Haiti's peasants, especially the land-less and land-poor, have historically cleared forest to expand agriculture and harvested trees to market timber and charcoal. Peasants also exploit forest stocks in times of economic insecurity to finance unexpected contingencies. In many situations, the unsustainable exploitation of trees or forest is the only remaining income-generating option available to peasants. 1.6 The pace of degradation of forest resources accelerated rapidly over the last several decades and Haiti's once abundant forests have diminished to a remnant.' Forests are now reduced to small and isolated patches and associated with steep ravines, high mountain peaks and coastal mangrove areas. As a result, associated plant and animal species are severely reduced in number and many species face extinction. This degradation is driven by the forces mentioned above, only exacerbated by increases in population and rural poverty. In addition to on-site biological damage, deforestation contributes to soil erosion which in turn endangers water supplies and contributes to soil erosion. This erosion decreases agricultural productivity, which is already half of the Latin American average. At the same time, sedimentation affects hydro-energy supply, blocks drainage systems, impedes use of port facilities and destroys marine ecosystems near the shore. Environmental degradation is undercutting the productivity of the over 70 percent of Haitians who reside in rural areas, and threatens to undermine all future national economic development. The GEF sponsored study mentioned above, that classified Hispaniola's moist and pine forest habitats regionally outstanding, concluded that these habitats were endangered and in the highest category of priority for protection at the regional level. 1.7 Although Haiti has an impressive number of laws and regulations to protect natural resources, these are largely either inappropriate, inconsistent or incomplete, and the Government lacks the capacity to enforce them. The existing natural resource legislation is poorly adapted to the socio-economic context of rural Haiti, emphasizing prohibition with little attention to incentives. The historic situation of inappropriate regulations, incapable enforcement and an unformed public establish a situation where incentives are perverse, the potential for extortion high, and distortions are almost certainly pervasive. For example, tree harvesting, even on private land, is officially prohibited except by permit from the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR), thereby creating a disincentive for farmers to adopt forestry practices. Although according to MARNDR officials this particular policy is not currently enforced, national-level officials do not have the means to know whether field agents are continuing to demand payment. 1.8 A majority of the remaining contiguous, closed-cover forest in Haiti is located in and around three national reserves -- the Pine Forest National Reserve, the Pic Macaya National Park, and the La Visite National Park. Fortunately, these three areas encompass the habitats of a great number of threatened and endangered endemic animal and plant species. For example, some 80 percent of remaining Haitian bird species are represented in the La Visite National Park. Unfortunately, these reserves face steady encroachment for agricultural production and illegal harvesting, and have recently become a new target for commercial charcoal harvesters for the urban market. A substantial percentage of local inhabitants hold insecure claims to state land. 1.9 Agriculture Sector Agriculture in terms of GDP contribution and employment remains Haiti's most important economic sector, although its contribution has been declining and is expected to continue its long-term decline. The decline is explained by, among other factors, a lack of rural infrastructure, historic under-investment in rural human capital, world decline in commodity prices and exposure to competition, stagnant production technology, almost complete absence of formal credit sources and the relentless pressure of the population on the country's very limited cultivable land resources. These factors have led to unviably small farm sizes, overexploitation of land, increases in the land values, and declining productivity per hectare and per worker. These problems are complicated by a fluid and complex land tenure situation that can discourage rational use of the available land resources. In addition, Government support services, which should promote technological change, are practically non-existent. Structural and policy changes in recent years include the demise of the sugar industry, the removal of quantitative protection for traditional crops such as maize and rice, government subsidy of rice imports, and the reduction or elimination of export taxes, now benefiting producers of coffee, sisal and cocoa. International market developments have generally negatively impacted on Haiti, in particular the significant decline of coffee and cocoa prices since early 1989. 1.10 Information on Haiti's land use is limited to 1978 aerial photographs, which indicate that nearly 80 percent of Haiti's area is devoted to agriculture in the broad sense, including 62 percent for crop use and 18 percent extensive grazing. The net cultivated area represents 11,900 kM2, or 44 percent of Haiti's land area. Twenty eight percent of the net cultivated area is in tree crops, 13 percent in specialized crops, e.g., rice, and 59 percent in food crops mostly grown in the hilly areas.2 Against this pattern of extensive land use are the estimates of BDPA that only 7,700 km2 (or 28 percent of the total land area) is appropriate for conventionally mechanized agriculture. Available data for 1987, show that about 65 percent of households could be classified as very poor. Households with an average income one half the poverty threshold represented about 40 percent of the total population. A recent study in Southern Haiti, the area of project intervention, estimated average annual per capita income at US$120. The majority of this income derives from agriculture, and secondly from petty commerce. Average annual net expenditures were estimated at US$102. Female-headed households were significantly poorer than male-headed, and over 20 percent of the population had annual incomes of less than US$ 30. B. Institutional Responsibilities and Constraints 1.12 A wide variety of institutions operate within the natural resources sector in Haiti. Major Governmental entities include the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR), the Ministry of the Environment (MDE). These institutions have, in general, broad mandates yet extremely limited capacities to execute. The bulk of the operational interventions in the natural resources and energy sectors, especially over the last three decades, have been conducted by non-governmental organizations (NGOs). NGOs range tremendously in size, technical competence and administrative capacity. These efforts are uncoordinated, and their impacts often important, yet limited to local levels. 1.13 Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR). The three principal objectives of MARNDR, as stated in its organic law, are to promote agriculture, conservation and utilization of natural resources, and rural development. Currently, the central structure of the Ministry is divided into Directorates. There are four technical directorates (Livestock, Agriculture, Natural Resources, Rural Development) charged with setting national strategy and policy in their respective domain. In addition to the technical directorates, there is a Directorate of Training and Continuing Education (DFPC), and a Directorate of Administration and a Directorate for each of the nine regional Departments. These departmental directorates are charged with executing and monitoring programs, and are each divided into sub-offices, one for each of the 132 rural communes. The Minister is assisted by a Director General who, in addition to supervising all Directorates, supervises a technical secretariat and three other units: Unit of Monitoring, Evaluation and Planning (UPSE), Center of Agricultural Development Research (CRDA), and a machinery park. The departmental directorates report to the Director General, and not directly to the specialized directorates or services. 1.14 Each directorate comprises a number of services for the different activities it is supposed to provide. The Directorate of Natural Resources (DRN) comprises the following six services: Irrigation and Rural Engineering, Soil Conservation, Water Resources, Forest Resources, Meteorology, National Parks and Natural Sites, and
 Aquaculture and Fishing. However, most of these services are neither fully staffed nor funded, and therefore have a limited ability to perform useful functions. The National Parks and Natural Sites Service (SPNS) was created in January 1996 and is staffed with a single individual with no program responsibilities. The SPNS was established on a temporary basis, with the intent of transferring it to the Ministry of Environment (MDE) upon passage of the MDE's organic law. The Forest Resources Service (SRF), which was the primary focus of the World Bank-funded Pilot Forestry Project, is nominally subdivided into five sections: management of natural forests, reforestation and agroforestry, forestry statistics, and forestry research, although these sections are not staffed. The personnel of the SRF entails a Chief of the Service, an Assistant Chief, one agronomist, five agroforestry technicians, four forestry agents, and nine support staff. Besides the Chief, who promotes forestry initiatives on a national level, staff efforts focus on the Foret des Pins, National Forest Reserve. 1.15 MARNDR's effectiveness is constrained both by its structure and its limited funding. Over the last several decades MARNDR's budget has constituted less than 3 percent of the national budget, and over 75 percent of this budget is expended on salaries. The existing structure is highly centralized and causes problems of coordination, in particular between the departmental directorates, the regional development organizations, and the technical directorates of the central Ministry. Units operate independently without clear lines of command and responsibilities. Consequently, duplications of activities and waste of time and resources are common. For example, the CRDA, responsible for technology generation and transfer, has no official relationship with the departmental directorates, responsible for agricultural extension. Decentralization has long been proposed as a means of increasing and improving the delivery of services to the rural areas, and was, in fact, included in a 1982 Law, the 1987 Constitution, and a 1991 plan to reorganize the Ministry. However, no serious attempts have been made to streamline MARNDR's operations. Past efforts were stifled by a very high turn-over of ministers and senior staff, and the resultant discontinuity of policies and strong political focus of all activities. The return of constitutional government and anticipated political stability provides an opportunity to address these issues. In 1995 the Ministry requested the FAO to assist in preparing a reorganization plan, but this plan was rejected by early 1996. There are no new reorganization plans currently being considered. 1.16 Ministry of the Environment. The Ministry of the Environment (MDE) was created by presidential decree in January of 1995 with a global mandate to protect Haiti's environment. The MDE's specific mission and organizational structure are to be specified with the passing of its organic law, which the Ministry submitted to Parliament during the month of December 1995. The MDE is currently organized in the following manner: The Minister is assisted by a personal Cabinet composed of three advisors (on a consultant basis). The Director General, who directs the MDE line staff, is advised by a Technical Secretariat composed of three technical experts (consultants). Line staff is organized in four sections: Administration (ten persons); NEAP Coordination (two technical staff and four consultants); Special Projects (two technical staff); and a Technical Team (two
 - 7 - technical staff and three consultants). The MDE has received institutional and project support mainly from USAID and UNDP. 1.17 Miscellaneous Institutions. Other institutional responsibilities for the management of natural resources are found below. The impact of these institutions is marginal, due to a lack of resources. (i) The Minyistry of Economy and Finance. Through its tax authority, Direction Generale des Imp6ts (DGI), the Ministry manages the "private domain of the state," i.e., state land that can be leased out, sold, donated or homesteaded to individuals or corporations under contractual arrangements (this is in contrast to the "public domain of the state," which is administered by other ministries and can also be leased out but not alienated; national parks would belong to this latter category of landholding; (ii) The Inistitlute for the Safeguard of the Nationial Patrimony (ISPAN). This is a semi-autonomous Government agency under the Ministry of Education that shares jurisdiction over national parks with the DRN; (iii) The National Tourism Office. This agency shares jurisdiction over parks; and (iv) The Minlistry of Planning and External Cooperation. The Ministry is charged with monitoring NGOs and land use planning. 1.18 NGOs in the Natural Resources Sector. NGOs have been the leading service providers, and the leading centers for technical expertise in the agriculture and natural resources sectors, since the early 1 980s when bilateral donors suspended assistance to the Government. A survey conducted in 1989 found that over 300 NGOs provided rural development services and that over 100 promoted tree planting. During the late 1980s, and until the 1991 couip d'etat, total bilateral aid alone administered by NGOs in the agriculture and natural resources sector is estimated to have exceeded US$ 10 million annually. NGOs vary greatly in size, development philosophy and technical competence. The NGOs with the greatest impact are the large international organizations with funding from bilateral donors (e.g. CARE, the Pan American Development Foundation (PADF)). These two organizations alone were providing agricultural extension services to over 30,000 peasants a year during the early 1990s. Local, Haitian NGOs (e.g. GRAMIR, GATAP, GRD, SEFADES, ASSODLO) execute a wide variety of rural development and natural resources projects and are gaining in number, expertise and administrative competence. Some of the smaller NGOs (e.g. World Neighbors and the Mennonite Central Committee) have been the source of significant technical and institutional innovations in the sector. C. Lessons From Experience Country Lessons 1.19 MajorAgroforestryProjects (Agroforestry Outreach Project (AOP) (1981-1989); Agroforestry II (AFII) (1990-1991); and Productive Land Use Systems (PLUS) (1992-1999). These were the largest natural resource management projects in Haiti since 1980 and were all financed by USAID. The objective of the AOP was to promote commercial tree production on private farm land without affecting food crop production.
 - 8 - USAID contributed US$27 million to this program between 1981 and 1990. During this period about 50 million tree seedlings were distributed, involving more than 200,000 farms. Key lessons from the AOP and the AFII with relevance to the project include: (a) using local NGOs as vehicles for extension packages was effective and efficient; (b) peasants are eager to plant trees, especially when assured of harvest rights, and when these trees can be easily integrated into their traditional agroforestry systems; (c) investments in soil conservation usually yield more significant economic and environmental benefits that tree planting; and (d) that peasants are eager to voluntarily adopt soil conservation techniques when they require low labor inputs and can be easily integrated into their farming system. These lessons are common across natural resource management projects operating in Haiti during the 1980s. The PLUS project was designed to integrate these lessons. It targets farm sites where production can be intensified with simple soil conservation practices. The PLUS project demonstrates that it is possible to simultaneously enhance family food security and yield environmental benefits, and to do so in a cost-efficient manner. A key lesson from the major agroforestry projects is that such efforts conducted outside of government structures further weaken government capacity (by offering better salaries and working conditions to trained personnel, and thus drawing technical staff away from the Ministry) and causing even greater resentment and distrust between the government and NGO communities. The proposed Forest and Parks Protection Technical Assistance Project (FPPTAP) will integrate these lessons by hiring competent NGOs to promote the proven hillside technologies under the strict technical supervision of government authorities. In this manner, the project seeks to build a positive partnership between NGOs and government authorities where each profit from the others' role and competence. 1.20 Macaya Biosphere Reserve (MBR) Project, University of Florida (1987-1992). This project was the largest park protection and buffer zone management project in the history of Haiti. It was also funded by USAID. The principal objective of the MBR project was to protect the natural ecosystems (forests) and natural resources of the Pic Macaya and surrounding areas, and thus assure the sustainable development of the park's watershed area. Activities included: (a) planning the management of the park and functional zoning for appropriate land use; (b) assisting the 1,750 peasants in the MBR to increase agricultural production using ecologically appropriate methods; (c) rehabilitating critical zones that have been environmentally degraded (e.g. steep slopes, springs, endangered habitats); and (d) establishing an informational (data) history of the Pic Macaya area. Project leaders distilled the following lessons after project closure in 1990: (a) park protection cannot be achieved in a short-term period, long-term funding and activities must be assured; (b) public support and local participation are essential to project success, as well as the support of associated politicians and counterpart governmental institutions; (c) co-management of the project, with the communities of the park area, must be well established during the design phase to ensure local ownership; (d) because income generation will be the overriding concern of the local community, a project can easily become a mere source of livelihood for community participants, distorting the base for any efforts at co-management; and (e) due to common social hierarchies, careful selection and inclusion of local leaders as co-managers is essential in order to ensure a
 - 9 - broader community support for project efforts. The FPPTA Project will integrate these lessons by establishing permanent advisory co-management advisory councils composed of representatives of local public and private organizations, and by establishing the basis for long-term government presence in the Park areas. The project will also assure the judicious use of labor-intensive projects to diminish the possibility of increasing immigration and local dependence on government subsidized incomes. 1. 21 Pic Macaya Protection Project (PPM), UNICORS (1992- i 996). The PPM is the follow-on to the MBR project described above. The PPM was designed to integrate some of the lessons from the MBR project and focused more squarely on improving local incomes and local participation in park management decisions. UNICORS, a local cooperative of coffee producers with substantial private land holdings within the National Park Boundary, was invited by USAID to implement the project. Most of the lessons from the PPM are not different from those generated by the MBR. One particular lesson is important, and that is that it is critical to hire service providers that are locally perceived as fair and competent. UNICORS has been highly contentious, both because it is a large landowner within the Park, and is seen by many as having a unfair vested interest in Park development, rather that protection, and because it is a peasant cooperative with no previous experience managing parks or executing major development programs. Two additional lessons from national park management experience in Haiti are instructive: (a) authoritative presence is requisite; and (b) basic protcction need not necessarily be costly. Large-scale harvesting and invasions immediately followed the suspension of guard services and extension projects in the Pic Macaya Park and Pine Forest Reserve after the military coup of 1991. On the other hand, the La Visite Park was left largely untouched. The only known difference is that a private individual paid La Visite park guard salaries during the entire military regime period at a cost of about US$50 per month. Sector Lessons 1.22 Natural Reserve and Buffer Zone Management. An independent assessment of Bank-supported protected area projects in 1993 concluded that: (a) too little consideration had been given to local people, their expertise and their priorities; (b) NGO services should have been used to a greater extent; and (c) long-term financing of such projects was sometimes doubtful. Similar observations are found in the 1991 OED analysis of forestry and conservation lending. 1.23 The principal lesson is that projects which have focused on purely biological concerns, and have attempted to insulate the project site from surrounding economic and social pressures, have often failed. The FPPTAP embodies the thesis that protection of the biodiversity assets in the protected areas can only be achieved through significant change in social and economic factors affecting the lives of people who live and work in and around the reserves.

Bank experience with decentralized rural development funds in Colombia and Mexico indicates that programs can be successful when they: (a) give target group representatives a central role in program design and grant selection; (b) clearly define objectives from the outset and explicitly focus on enhancing rural management capacity; (c) have simple, widely publicized procedures and respond rapidly, transparently and flexibly to proposals; (d) do not follow normal government procurement and administration procedures; and (e) are apolitical and perceived to be fair. In addition, evaluations found weaknesses in the technical quality of some subprojects as well as limitations in the selection of subprojects. Non-governmental and bilateral organizations have substantial experience funding productive projects in rural Haiti. Their experience indicates that success is dependent upon quality, locally trusted, technical assistance and close monitoring and evaluation. The FPPTAP was designed to benefit from the above experiences by establishing a low-profile, decentralized, demand-driven facility, and allocating funds on a formula basis, ensuring both consistency, adequate technical assistance, and fairness. Previous Bank Involvement in the Sector 1.25 National Forestry Project (PFN). The National Forestry Project, a pilot operation that was implemented by MARNDR between 1982 and 1989, was financed jointly by IDA (Credit 1257-HA, with US$4.0 million disbursed), the Government (US$0.75 million), the International Research Center (US$0.3 million), and the French Agency for Voluntary Services (US$0.6 million). The objectives of the project were: (a) the strengthening of the MARNDR's Forest Service; (b) education and training in forestry; (c) species trials for the production of woodfuel on 3 50 ha; (d) pilot plantations for woodfuel production and a trial to determine the production impact of protection measures for the local savanna vegetation; (e) partial management of the Pine Forest on 5,750 ha; (f) promotion of improved cooking stoves for wood and charcoal; and (g) the preparation of a large-scale follow-up project. Policy objectives included: (a) building up the operational capacity of the Forest Service, including a strong extension element; (b) enacting and applying new forestry legislation; and (c) developing economically viable reforestation and forest management practices. The project was also to design a long-term plan for forestry development. 1.26 The project had a slow start, suffered from shortages of counterpart funds and political disturbances, and to complete the project, the IDA credit had to be extended by two and a half years. Nevertheless, the project largely achieved its quantitative targets, except for the primary education component, and the introduction of improved cooking stoves. It was less successful in realizing its policy objectives. The enactment of new forest legislation and the preparation of a long-term forestry development plan did not materialize. Extension activities were limited to a partial census and some land leases in the Pine Forest. Certain technical results, in particular those relating to the pilot plantations, require further confirmation. In particular, the pilot plantings faced opposition and intrusions from the local populations, and suffered from cattle damage and erratic rainfall. The lessons identified in the Project Completion Report for this project include:

In addition, these activities would yield important downstream off-site benefits including greater efficiency in irrigation system and a reduction in flood related damages. The Buffer Zone Development Component, by increasing agricultural productivity, diversifying income sources, and generating employment options, as well as enhancing local natural resource management capabilities, would improve the welfare of the rural household, conserve natural resources and reduce pressures for encroachment in the protected areas. Forest and National Park Management Component 5.2 On-site benefits. Within the protected areas, three main categories of benefits are likely to be generated: preservation of biodiversity, recreational/tourist benefits, and harvest of forest products. Preservation of biodiversity. The three protected areas, and particularly the Pic Macaya and La Visite National Parks, are important natural habitats because of their genetic diversity, including many species endemic to the area and few such ecosystems remain in Hispaniola. Because of its altitude range, the Macaya area supports mature broad-leaved forests as well as cloud forest, thus creating numerous
 -25 - micro-catchments with a rich diversity of species. Of the nearly 500 flora recorded in the Macaya, about a third are endemic to Hispaniola and 15 percent to the Macaya area. Aside from its rich diversity of birds, the area is also a wintering area for numerous species from North America. Both of the surviving land mammals of Hispaniola are found in the Macaya area. The La Visite area, containing hardwood forest on the steep slopes and pine forest on the central plateau, has over 308 species of vascular plants, including 90 species (29 percent) endemic to Hispaniola and 36 (11 percent) endemic to the Massif de la Selle. In addition, over 20 species of butterflies, 45 species of land mollusks, at least 12 species of amphibians, and 67 species of birds are reported in the area of the proposed park. Of the 21 endemic bird species on Hispaniola, 17 (81 percent) are found inside the park area. 5.3 Recreational/tourist benefits. The parks and forest have considerable potential for recreational use by Haitians and for attracting foreign tourists, especially in light of the growing interest in eco-tourism worldwide. At present, there is no significant tourism in either the La Visite or the Pic Macaya National Parks. But, based on the experience of other countries in the region, notably Costa Rica, it is not unreasonable to expect that the Pic Macaya National Park might attract several thousand tourists a year, as long as its cloud forest habitat and its rich avifauna are preserved (the avifauna is probably particularly important from a marketing viewpoint, since the town of Cayes is the birthplace of ornithologist John Audubon). Revenue from modest entrance fees alone would be sufficient to cover between 10 to 40 percent of the parks' recurrent costs. 5.4 The major economic benefits would be derived from the attraction of additional tourism, leading to longer stays and higher per tourist expenditures. The experience of Costa Rica suggests that both effects are likely to be significant. In Costa Rica, where eco-tourism has been aggressively marketed, it is estimated that there are over 300,000 eco-tourists annually, each spending on average per visit more than US$1,000. Conservatively, if earnings per tourist in Haiti were half the level observed in Costa Rica, the present value of the resulting income stream would reach US$15.0 million. However, since realizing this potential would require additional investments in roads, these benefits are not considered in the economic analysis for this project. 5.5 Harvesting offorest products. While no cutting would be carried out in the national parks, in the multi-purpose national forest reserve of Foret des Pins, the project envisages thinning operations and Christmas tree production. No commercial logging would be carried out during the life of the project. Thinning would generate wood products with an approximate financial value of US$20,000 annually, while Christmas tree production would, after eight years, generate about US$14,000 annually. The benefits from these activities would be distributed to local communities. The present value of these income streams is about US$0.3 million. In the longer term, after the forest management plans have been developed, some parts of the forest might be zoned for sustainable commercial forestry. Many products are currently harvested from the project areas, including fuel wood, fodder (both by collection and by direct grazing of animals), bwa gra (resinous sticks used to Lght charcoal fires), fruit, and various herbs for medicinal
 -26- or aromatic purposes. The project would assess which of these activities could be continued on a sustainable basis. 5.6 Off-site benefits. The off-site benefits would be directed to the rural communities living in the downstream areas. These benefits would stem from an improvement in efficiency of existing irrigation systems, lower irrigation O&M costs, and a mitigation of farm losses due to flood damage. The three protected areas are near the summits of mountain ranges: the Pic Macaya on the Massif de la Hotte and La Visite and Foret des Pins on the Massif de la Selle. Deforestation in these mountainous areas has already caused considerable downstream damage resulting both from erosion and changes in local hydrology. Sedimentation is causing considerable damage to irrigation capacity by silting diversion dams and distribution canals. This problem is particularly marked in the Plaine des Cayes, an important agricultural area downstream of the Pic Macaya National Park. The heavy sediment loads of rivers originating in the project areas frequently result in flooding and river course changes, both of which cause substantial damage to agriculture, urban areas, and roads. In addition, increased run-off resulting from deforestation in the upper reaches of the watersheds is increasing the incidence of flooding during the wet season and water scarcities for both irrigation and domestic use during the dry season. 5.7 Greater irrigation efficiency. Estimated off-site benefits include those derived from containment and/or reduction of the damage to irrigation systems. In the Macaya area, under the without project scenario, it was assumed that, due to deterioration of the irrigation systems, 5 percent of the irrigated area would be abandoned annually'. This was compared against two project scenarios: one, in which the irrigated area would remain constant; and the other, in which the irrigated area would be increased 1.25 percent annually. On the basis of these conservative assumptions, the present value of the benefits from reduced damage to irrigation resulting from project interventions would be about US$4.0 million to US$20 million. These benefits refer only to those related to gains in agricultural production and do not include those benefits related to reduced O&M costs. 5.8 Reduction in flood related damages. Areas downstream from the project sites are subject to frequent flooding, causing loss of standing crops and damage to infrastructure, including roads, irrigation canals, and houses. Floodings, which had been relatively infrequent (occurring once every four to five years), now occur regularly twice a year, effecting an increasingly larger area. The floodings in Camp-Perrin of June 1986, one of the few floods for which there are historical records, was estimated to have caused over US$1.0 million in damages to the embankments at Camp-Perrin and Cayes, agricultural production, and buildings and other infrastructure. 5.9 The estimated cost of flood related damages is limited only to those costs related to damages to infrastructure. An estimation of the cost of flood related crop damages was not made as the actual damages depend upon many unknown factors including the type and the intensity of the crops involved, as well as the depth and duration of the flooding. 5 Based on available historical records for the Avezac, Dubreuil and Torbeck irrigation systems in the Plaine des Cayes.

In addition, it would be reasonable to assume that, in the absence of the project, continued natural degradation would increase flooding intensity and frequency and that the costs of the associated damages could double. Assuming that such averted damages are reduced by only by 25 percent over five years, the present value of these losses would be about US$1.0 million. This, in addition to the benefits stemming from the containment of damages, would yield a benefit with a present value between US$3.5 million and US$6.0 million. 5.10 Additional benefits. Although not considered in the economic analysis, there are additional benefits, related to hydroelectric power (HEP) and transportation facilities, would stem from this component. Haiti has an acute power shortage, developing its HEP potential will not be possible unless upstream degradation is substantially reduced. Some of the planned buffer zone activities in the Pic Macaya area could help protect the Cavaillon river watershed above the Saut Mathurine hydroelectric power (HEP) plant, whose reservoir is being rapidly silted up. The Saut-Mathurine HEP plant has an installed production capacity of 2.4MW. Other downstream benefits of arrested or reduced natural resource degradation in the project include decreased silting in the port of Cayes, increase in fish stocks and control of the intrusion of saltwater into coastal aquifers. 5.11 Component Costs6. The estimated present value of cost of this component, including investment, recurrent and opportunity costs in foregone income, would be US$6.0 million. Certain economic activities are expected to be curtailed as a result of better park and reserve management, particularly some agricultural and logging activities. Based on the farm models, the present value of foregone income resulting from the diversion of agricultural lands would be about US$2.1 million. The value of forgone logging income could not be estimated as reliable data on standing timber volume and the logging trade are not available. However, the degree of degradation of the remaining forests with reasonable road access would indicate that the economic value of forgone logging income is likely to be insignificant. 5.12 Conclusions. To gauge the economic viability of the component, the present value of the component's economic costs was compared against the present value of its calculable benefits. The present value of the aggregated component costs, including investment, recurrent and opportunity costs, of US$6.0 million was compared against the present value of the quantified benefits. These benefits included: (i) increased efficiency of existing irrigation systems, yielding an estimated present value of benefits of between US$4.0 million and US$20 million; and (ii) the mitigation of flood related-damages, resulting in an estimated present value of benefits of between US$3.5 million and US$6.0 million. Combined present value of these benefits would range between US$7.5 million to US$26 million. All costs and benefits are expressed in present values, applying a 10 percent discount rate and, in most cases, an infinite time horizon.

Environmental Aspects 5.18 The project has been approved as Environmental Assessment Category "B." It would have a positive impact on the protection of the protected areas and the conservation of soil and forest resources in the surrounding areas. It will establish a Park Service that will be able to identify and protect new reserves in the future, especially those that are currently not well represented and it would identify financial mechanisms to ensure adequate habitat protection in the future. Sustainability 5.20 Evaluations of investments in protected areas indicate that there are two common constraints to achieving sustained impacts: insecure and insufficient financing, and inadequate management. This project will provide adequate funding during the life of the project and make concerted efforts towards establishing the Park (SPNS) and Forest Resources (SRF) Services as efficient, well structured organizations that have the capacity to plan, coordinate and evaluate technical operations. During the life of the project, options for a sustainable financing mechanism will be explored to assure long-term funding for recurrent protection costs, as well as incremental costs for complementary conservation/sustainable use activities. Recommendations from this analysis could constitute the basis for a future request to the GEF. The project will also support the Government's recommendation to eventually establish an autonomous government agency whose function would be to manage national protected areas. The autonomous structure is advantageous for a number of reasons: (i) autonomous agencies have greater political autonomy and programmatic flexibility than Ministerial Services; (ii) such agencies are able to raise private funds and sign contracts with other agencies; and thus (iii) the autonomous structure would enhance the Park Service's ability to attract private funds and liase with civic organizations. 5.21 The issues of inadequate reserve management and sustained encroachment will be addressed by providing income generating options for the poor in reserve buffer areas, and by establishing representative and transparent Advisory Committees that are empowered to assure local voice in reserve management decision, and equitable distribution of tangible benefits from the reserves. In order to enhance the probability of sustaining the benefits and behaviors generated by the household energy component, it will build on and improve existing institutions, products and markets, rather than create new structures. Interventions will be carefully designed so that all participants will be able to either earn more money or save on fuel expenditures.

Risks 5.22 The main risks of the project relate to: (i) uncertain political stability which may impact on continued Government commitment to its declared development strategy, project funding, and efficient management and functioning of the implementing agencies; (ii) weak coordination and management capacity of central and local government and private agencies to implement the project; and (iii) the "success" of buffer zones development activities that could attract in-migration.  ANNEX E Buffer Zone Small Investment Facility: Eligibility Principles

 -65- ANNEX E HAITI FOREST AND PARKS TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT Buffer Zone Small Investment Facility: Eligibility Principles 1. Poverty Targeting: Buffer Zone Small Investment Facility (BZSIF) sub-projects will benefit the poor. The types of eligible sub-projects will help ensure high coverage of poor people. 2. Benericiary Participation: Sub-projects will be identified, designed and executed by beneficiary-groups proposing the sub-projects. 3. Bencficiary Cost-Sharing: The beneficiary group will be required to make a counterpart contribution, either in cash or kind, towards financing of the project. This contribution will be no less than 20 percent of the total cost of the project. 4. Eligibility Criteria: The BZSIF will finance three categories of sub-projects within the buffer zones of the project areas: (a) small income generation projects; (b) applied agricultural research; and (c) conservation of public natural resources. Individuals may not propose projects and projects for individual benefit will not be considered. The first category would include activities such as grain storage, agricultural transformation, input retailing, credit, soil conservation, agroforestry, technical assistance or training. The second category would include activities such as on-farm trials and testing techniques for transforming agricultural products. Peasant membership organizations from within the buffer zones with a history of collective action will be eligible for categories (a) and (b). The third category would include activities that generate or protect community-level public, natural resources, such as soil conservation to protect public ravines, ecotourism development, and study tours, technical assistance or training related to such activities. Local governments - at the Rural Section and Commune level - %vithin the buffer zones will be eligible to submit proposals for category (b) Projects in category (c) would conform to a local development plan approved by the Ministry of Environment. 5. Project Sponsorship: The BZSIF will not sponsor projects. It will respond to the demand for projects. The BZSIF will provide technical assistance to beneficiary groups to assist them in identifying and articulating their project proposals. 6. Project Implementation: The BZSIF will not implement the projects on its own, nor will it employ the services of local contractors to implement the projects. The projects will be implemented by the beneficiary-group, who - where appropriate - will employ the services of sub-contractors to assist in implementing the projects. These sub-contractors would be chosen on a competitive basis and approved by the BZSIF. 7. Sustainability: The BZSIF will not provide resources to supplement recurrent expenditures. BZSIF support will be conditional upon confirmation that resources (private and public) will be made available to meet recurrent expenditures. 8. Complementarity: The BZSIF will collaborate with the Ministry of Environment, the Forest Resources Service of the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR), and the National Parks and Natural Sites Service (MARNDR) to ensure complementarity of objectives. 9. Project Size: Any sub-project exceeding US$50,000 will require the non-objection of the Bank. 10. Project Costs and Benefits: Projects will employ least cost designs and deliver maximum benefits for a given cost. Projects will be appraised according to standard methods of measuring costs and benefits.

doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Forest and Parks Protection Technical Assistance Project is to start the initial phase of intervention for the protection of critical remnants of Haiti's forest ecosystems and for slowing the pace of degradation of Haiti's forest resouces. The three specific objectives of the project are to: a) provide institutional support to the Ministry of Environment and related services within the Ministry of Agriculture, of Natural Resources and of Rural Development for strengthening the Government's isntitutional forest and parks protection system; b) initiate key activities to protect and manage specific parks; and c) reduce pressure on protected areas by increasing on-farm productivity and off-farm employment options conserving natural resources, and enhancing the management capacity of local organizations. The project will achieve its objectives by financing technical assistance, technical and policy studies, training, equipment, limited civil works, and incremental operating costs required to implement the following components: a) institutional strengthening and reform; b) support for the management of forest and national parks; and c) suport for the buffer zone development
